abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Livestock Disease
            Control Project in Brazil are as follows: overall outcome of
            the project is satisfactory, performance of the Bank was
            rated satisfactory, and performance of the Borrower was also
            rated satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the
            project are: 1) livestock and plant disease control programs
            should be linked to a government strategy which specifies
            the policy position for the agricultural sector including
            the livestock and plant subsectors, and its links to export
            growth, and shows concrete evidence of being carried out; 2)
            state level producer associations and municipalities have
            tremendous potential to participate with government in
            animal and plant disease control/eradication programs but
            this needs simpler, more practical mechanisms which avoid
            legal and operational difficulties; 3) Project
            organizational structure and lines of responsibility must be
            simple, clear and rational, heeding political realities and
            the incentives system affecting the performance of public
            and other agencies. Project coordinating units should stress
            decentralized operations, simplified processes and lean
            staffing; and 4) a project operating manual, with
            comprehensive rules and norms for project operation, and
            flexible enough to permit project modification, can be an
            important factor in spreading the idea and initiating the
            practice of decentralization.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Livestock Disease Control Project
            seeks to increase livestock productivity by decreasing
            production losses resulting from disease.  In order to
            achieve this objective, the project aims to assist the
            Ministry of Agriculture in transforming the existing federal
            and state veterinary departments into modern, cost-effective
            services.  To this end, the Livestock Disease Control
            Project is the first Bank-financed project in Brazil to be
            directly implemented by the Ministry of agriculture.  It
            intends to (a) strengthen the Federal Government's
            Department of Animal Health Protection through recruitment
            and training of staff, management training, employment of
            consultant services and purchase of field equipment; (b)
            strengthen 15 state veterinary services through training and
            the purchase of equipment; and (c) increase and improve the
            quality of staff at nine federal laboratories belonging to
            the Department of Animal Disease Laboratories through staff
            recruitment, training and the use of consultant services.
            Further to this, the project seeks to (d) improve the
            physical facilities at the nine federal laboratories, one
            state laboratory in Rio Grande do Sul, the Panamerican
            Center for Foot-and-Mouth Disease outside Rio and four
            quarantine stations.  The project would concentrate on
            cattle, pig and poultry production.
